messageBody:
The number of tests that you have in your test class should be
proportional to the number of methods that you have in the class to be
tested. And, I wouldn't think you'd average more than three tests per method
to be tested.

So, given your example, to have a test class with 500 tests, the
class being tested would have to have nearly 200 methods, which seems like
an awful lot for a single class! I could see how having perhaps 100 tests in
a test class would be possible, but that would be to test a rather sizable
class. Also, chances are the code for the entire test class would be smaller
than the code for the class being tested, which would make it a bit more
managable.

So, I'd say if you've got that many test methods floating about, you
may want to think about breaking up your classes somewhat. However, there's
nothing that says you can't create multiple test classes to test a single
class, then come up with some way to divvy up your tests (all null tests go
in one class, etc.).

-tim

p.s. I don't see how the example you provided really helps matters.
Yes, you've managed to reduce the number of methods, but not the overall
size of the test code.

Subject: [junit] A Growing Problem


A Growing Problem

The typical way of handling test cases in JUnit is to create a class
with methods beginning with "test". For example, we could create the
methods testNullAccount() and testEmptyAccount() to handle cases where
the account object is null and empty, respectively. This approach is
satisfactory for a few test cases, but what if the number of test cases
grows to 50 or even 500? It seems that there is always another test case
I should test for. Having this many methods becomes unmanageable. The
situation gets ugly.

You might work around this limitation by placing all test cases and
assert statements sequentially inside a single method. This approach
suffers from two limitations. The first limitation is the need to
replicate the test code for every test case. Even if you have only two
or three lines of code per test case, the size of the method will
mushroom and become hard to maintain (and read). See example below (
Taken from JavaPro ) -

public void testCreateBatchLabelNoInnerClass() {

try {
BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
"20010530", "A13", "1" );
assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
"A13-1 EXP. 05/01" ) ) ;
} catch (Exception e) {
assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
}

try {
BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
"20010530", "A13", "" );
assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
"A13 EXP. 05/01" ) ) ;
} catch (Exception e) {
assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
}

try {
BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
"20011231", "A13", "1" );
assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
"A13-1 EXP. 12/01" ) ) ;
} catch (Exception e) {
assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
}

try {
BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
"20010101", "A13", "1" );
assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
"A13-1 EXP. 01/01" ) ) ;
} catch (Exception e) {
assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
}

try {
BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
"20010101", "A123", "99" );
assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
"A123-99 EXP. 01/01" ) ) ;
} catch (Exception e) {
assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
}

try {
BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
"2001530", "A999", "" );
} catch (Exception e) {
assert( "Wrong Exception thrown: " + e,
e.getClass().equals(
BadDateException.class )) ;
}

try {
BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
"20010530", "913", "1" );
} catch (Exception e) {
assert( "Wrong Exception thrown: " + e,
e.getClass().equals(
BadLotException.class )) ;
}

// etc

}

The second limitation is that JUnit will stop the testing after the
first failure-the remaining test cases won't be executed.

What can be the solution on these two limitations?
